description.text: This is a respin of 3d0g's original key design seen here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:219561 Most of the pieces have pegs that press fit into matching holes. The only two that need to be glued together are the tube parts. Everything is printed at 100% in-fill to give the pegs the necessary strength, otherwise the top of them will break off. The key can be displayed two different ways as seen in the pictures above. There are holes both on the bottom as well as on the side depending on whether you want it sitting on your desk, or hanging on the wall. For a longer write-up and additional pictures of assembly, please visit: https://plus.google.com/112889495015752015404/posts/HBXYUqvkF1K

All parts are printed with 100% in-fill and a Brim
  • Join the rod and bottom parts together. You may need to do a bit of sanding on the pegs so it fits easier, but you want to keep it a snug fit.
  • Remove the two support pieces on the tube (that are holding the two half-moon pegs up during printing).
  • Glue the rod and bottom piece to the tube.
  • Press fit the side into the matching holes on the tube. Some sanding on the pegs will help if the fit is too tight.
  • Add the back part by fitting it on the half moon pegs.
  • Lastly place the key onto the base. For the side holes, you may need to enlarge the hole just a bit because of how the first layer gets squished onto the bed.
  • Sit back and enjoy!

title: iPhone 5 Case Optimized for PLA Slim Sturdy & Simple

description.text: This case is optimized to print in PLA and has not been tested with ABS. Previous designs I tried proved too thin to be practical with PLA. This case is the first I have been happy with after several design iterations. It is still a work in progress and I welcome your input. Please feel free to comment any and all suggestions you might have.

This file includes 4 .15mm circle supports on the corners of the case. These will need to be removed after printing but are well worth the effort. They will help to insure your case stays on the build plate through the entire print as well as prevent warping. Recommended Print Settings: Layer Height: .15
Infil: 100%
Shells: 1
Raft: No
Support: No Our Printer & Software Printer: Makerbot Replicator 2 Temperature: 225c Filament: 3rd Party Vendor Build Plate: Glass W/ Painters Tape Slicer: Makerware

comments.text: Hey, I'm interested in buying your build plate off ebay. I was just wondering if I could contact you because I live in Penn Valley and thought it would be easier to pick up/drop it off rather than ship it 3 blocks. Plus I also wanted to know how snug it fits into the makerbot plus the quality of the prints versus the acyrlic plate. Thanks
comments.author: Peoples-Exchange

comments.text:
Hello,
I am afraid my last build plate sold earlier today but I am still happy to answer some of your questions. The fit is made snug with the included rubber and foam bumpers. You place the bumpers on the the inside of the tabs on the platform. I personally feel there is a larger improvement in consistency and not quality when compared to acrylic. You will see a lot less failures due to parts lifting or a warped first layer. As far as quality goes the only real improvement is in the first layer wich will be glossy smooth on glass. The other and morst important improvement comes from large parts actually sticking to the build plate and not lifting in the corners. Check eBay for new inventory in the future and I would appreciate it if all business was kept on eBay and off of Thingiverse.
comments.author: jkeenan95

comments.text:
Yeah, unfortunately I've started to have problems printing larger objects due to the build plate becoming warped at the sides. I just wanted to make sure that it still sticks to the glass platform as well as it has on the acrylic, which you seemed to have answered :).
By the way I love this case, by far the best case I've printed on my makerbot. It came out really nice on the sides and snugly fits my iphone. Thanks for your help and all your great thingiverse things :).
comments.author: Peoples-Exchange

comments.text: Just to be clear you do need hairspray for a good stick on glass. I highly recommend Aquanet. 2-3 good even coats sprayed on the glass (Far away from the machine) will alleviate any and all "Sticking" problems. Thanks again for the kind words and best of luck with your printing!

author: Shieldse

description.text:
Magnetically Levitated Solar powered motor. I have been wanting to make one of these for while
So I reviewed many Mendocino motor designs online, from there took the basic concepts designed and built my own one. Could do with a few more refinements but very happy with the end result. Fun Project to build ... im still busy with with the build WIP . I just have to solder the solar panels on and see how it works and then make any adjustments accordingly - I will add a video once I have finished, If you have any questions - let me know. update 13 Feb 2015 : Soldering the solar panels to the coils hurt my soul , i didn't know soldering would be so hard and i see now i did not take into account the wires under the solar panels - should have made space to fit them underneath. i will redesign the rotor > separate the coils & the solar panels
making it better, easier to work with and test -- will upload V2 when im done. Update : 16th Feb
Tested Motor over the weekend - it works https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gv453GNQk8c&feature=youtu.be

You will need the following : Carbon Rod (ID 3mm OD 5mm) 2 meters in length to cut accordingly.
All Printed Parts
Magnets : (N35)
6 x Ring Magnet ID 5mm OD 25mm thickness 5mm
1 x Disc Magnet 25mm x 10mm
Solar Panels x 4
Magnet Wire - 300 turns per coil The Solar panels are wired in series to increase V
Two Solar panels per coil
end of one coil connected to the + of Solar panel 1 and - of Solar panel 2 and same for opposite end of coil

description.text:
This part is intended for the MakerBot Replicator 2 machine.  Used to mount PLA spools that use a 38mm Dia center hole on the back of the printer.
I bought PLA from a third party supplier and the spool did not work with the MakerBot supplied mount.  The MakerBot supplied mount is ~51mm in Dia but the PLA spools I bought have a smaller (38mm dia) center hole.  So, I created this new mount based on the MakerBot version but using a smaller diameter shaft.

I've included a .STL and a .STP file
You need to use "Raft" and "Supports" in your MakerWare software for this to print out correctly. Settings I used:
Quality: High
Raft + Supports
Infill = 100%
Number of Shells = 3
Layer Height = .1 Temperature and Speed: Use default settings
**Note that if you use these settings it will probably take all night to print out.
Using a lower quality will speed up the printing and should still produce a usable part. Break away all the support structure after it's done printing.

title: fan funnel reduction 25 to 50 mm for rebel2.stl

description.text:
I didn't want to buy small fan (25mm), because I head plenty of the bigger ones (50mm) when I needed a fan for my coldend (cooler) cooling. I had a 25mm fan cooler mount piece (blue on the photo) which came with the printer parts so I've done a reduction.
Originaly it is planned for a czech printer REBEL2, but you can use it with anyithing that works. You will need
  • <2, 4> M3 - 10mm bolts for the 50mm fan
  • <2> M2 - 5mm bolts for the reduction to cooler mount
    • As I didn't designed it with axial symetry - to be as high as possible (why not if I can :) ), so I didn't manage to insert M2 holes in every corner only in the two upper ones. So after bolting there is a small gap on the bottom, but nothing what the insulating tape would not handle ;) It printed just fine with slic3r over repetier host on 0.4 nozzle with PLA. I thickened the most tilted wall as it seemed a little too steep and thin.
blender - i like it :)

A simple little device to get you introduced to the world of InMoov. With this it should get you going easily to comprehend how to use an Arduino, a servo, and a robot finger. IMPORTANT: Before printing these files, check my website for the latest updates. This is going to be fun, if you never tried an Arduino and a servo together, we are going to make things very simple for you to learn. First a tuto for to assemble and print this baby InMoov and then a video tuto on how to start MRL in a very simple way to start playing with this. Once you understand how to control this toy, you should be ready, mentaly, to build the complete robot...(Mmmh maybe not, we will see) You can also buy this product here:
http://www.inmoov.fr/shop/ A little video: http://youtu.be/ZDbfrYfLwQE

Follow the tutorial instructions here:
http://www.inmoov.fr/finger-starter/
You can also buy this product here:
http://www.inmoov.fr/shop/
You might want to check the latest STL version here:
http://inmoov.fr/inmoov-stl-parts-viewer/?bodyparts=Finger-starter-kit Print each STL
You will need a servo motor and an Arduino board. We currently use HK15298 and MG995 and MG946R which have an average of 12kg torque. Of course you can use cheaper and less strong servos but they should respect the same size to fit in.
Use braided fishing line ( I use 200LB)

How I was able to realign and level my dual extruders after a repair.

I needed to clean a clog and replace the insulation around the heater. I downloaded this part as to make my life easier... But after reading 'einer_designs' description on what was done, I thought of another way. The idea was to remove the heater off the threaded shaft then attach the extruders nozzle to it using another source. I found a nut that had the same thread as the shaft and nozzle - this held the two parts together as they would be when installed onto the heater. After that I threaded the two parts in to the aluminum holder and attached the printed part. Now I was free to turn both parts down until I felt them hit the printed stopper - when they were both touching the part I tightened the nut up to the aluminum base to hold them from moving - I then installed the top nut to sintch it all tight so they would not loose their place when installing the heaters - I then removed the alignment part and twisted on the heaters... I did not go to tight with the heaters but wanted to make sure they were in the alignment as when I took them off - once in place I installed the nozzles and made sure they were very snug as to not let any plastic leak out between the seem.  That's it... It took a little messing with as I was trying to tighten the nozzles too much and it would break my alignment loose and I would loose my setup.  I found if I just snugged then down it worked. After reinstalling all the parts, and installing them back onto the machine, I re-levelled the build pad and completed some dual colour and single colour prints, can't be happier!!! Seems as thou both nozzles are aligned perfect or dam close to it!

comments.text: I wonder if you could press the nozzle into the plastic a little before you stopped.  You could get the setting very precise if you mounted a small metal plate on the holder, like a feeler gauge.  Connect multimeter leads to the plate and the barrel, and stop turning when you see the circuit complete.
comments.author: ianjohnson

comments.text: It could a wee bit... but what I found was when you tighten the nozzle to the heater the wrench used snugging the final assemble together has much more leverage so it does loose a hair of depth, since the nut used to hold the two parts together when doing the first adjustment is just finger tightened. Its not perfect but worked great for me.

description.text: Hair dryer holder, if you want a best result print it in ABS and use the "acetone vapours smoothing" technique.
I've printed it in ABS at 0,2mm. In PLA I think that can be a problem if the hair dryer becomes too hot.

This winder is a remake of the Lyman extruder filament puller (see
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:380987 ) . The original design is using a stepper motor, and this design a geared DC motor.
This design is more compact, with the motor on the back. I have used this motor to extrude lots of filament, and it really helps to keep the extruded filament nicely constant in diameter. It does not damage the filament in any way. It keeps it smooth surface and round shape. The pressure on the filament is made with 2 springs, and the pressure can be adjusted with the screws.
It holds the filament very good, and need quite a couple of kg pull force before it starts slipping.
In order to get the filament out, you need to lift the top parts. Getting it is in easy: just push it against the running rolls, and it is pulled in. The design uses a 60rpm motor. This gives a good adjustment range for both 3mm and 1.75mm filament extrude speeds. If the speed range is not matching your extruder, then the motor can be get in other RPM speeds.
Normally you only need to adjust to speed in the beginning for the correct diameter, and then it keeps that during the rest of the run The filament must be cooled before it enters the puller, otherwise it will be squashed to an oval shape. The design has place for 4 springs, but you only need 2 springs in opposite corners to get an good pressure on the filament. The top roller is an idler. It only function in life is to keep the filament pressed on the bottom driven roller. You can use the bare (abs, pla) printed version for this. It it slips that is no problem
The bottom roller needs to pull the filament, and thus need some surface with a lot of friction. For example you can use silicone, PU, latex or real rubber. Either in the form of a tube that is pulled over the plastic roller, or as solid material with a 8mm hole in the middle. I used an inkt rubber roller . In case the filament wanders to the side, use this: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:681880 for a smaller entry. The sprockets are a remix from the Mendel90 design ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:17826
) from nophead . The small is remixed for a smaller shaft hole. Some pictures of my plastic extruder setup are here : http://3dwingmaster.blogspot.co.nz/2016/02/filament-extruder-creating-my-own.html Please share your experiences with the extruder puller! Cheers!

I printed the design in PLA. I did not notice any melting if the idler roll, even when in contact with hot ABS filament for hours.
The 2 main parts will need support during printing. The inkt rubber roller must be cut it to size. Also needed to drill a 8mm hole through it. Also drilled a 2.5mm hole in the side for a m3 grub screw to hold it on the 8mm axel You need to print all parts 1x. Can be printed in PLA.
Don't print the extruder_assembly.stl ! Possible the roller is needed 2x. Parts:
  • To control the speed I use this voltage regulator: http://www.banggood.com/5A-XL4005-DC-DC-Adjustable-Step-Down-Module-Power-Supply-Converter-p-943556.html SKU124701
  • Motor is a 60rpm version: http://www.banggood.com/12V-DC-Powerful-Torque-Micro-Speed-Reduction-Gear-Box-Motor-p-941191.html SKU154499
  • Rubber coating or pully.. I used this: .http://www.banggood.com/Ink-Paint-Brayer-Painting-Roller-Printmaking-Tool-6_5CM11CM-p-963236.html SKU176928
  • Bold M8x120 with a hex head + nut(s) for he driven roller.
  • 1x Bold or 8mm (100mm) silver stell rod for the idler
  • 3x M3x5 grub screws + 3x M3 nut
  • 2x M4 screws and nuts
  • 2x strong spring
  • 4x bearing BB608
  • 2x m3 screws to hold the motor.
    • When using the paint roller is a bit tricky: This need to be drilled in the center with a 8 mm drill. You need to drill exactly straight through the middle of the roll, otherwise it would wobble. I didn't get that right and still left with a tiny wobble. Connecting the dc motor is quite simple.
    You need a small 12v to 24v power supply. Normally your filament extruder will have one already.
    Connect the 12v supply to the voltage regulator input.
    Connect the output of the voltage regulator to your motor.
    Watch the + and -. If the motor runs the wrong direction, swap the motor wires.
    Adjust speed by turning the (square blue) variable resistor on the voltage regulator. For 3mm filament with my DIY extruder I need run the motor at about 4volt. For 1.75 filament the voltage is higher, but have not created that yet.

author: kazuja

description.text:
Yes, another filament spool ! Advantages of this design are :
  • Large 100mm center preventing filament cracking and de-forming
  • It is 195mm in diameter. Hold easy 1 kg filament. Also (just) will fit most 3D printer beds.
  • Filament lock holes for both start and end of filament.
  • Large shaft center of 32mm fitting most 3d printer spool holders.
  • No other parts needed, except 2x m4 screws.
  • Little material as possible to speed up printing and reduce cost.
    • Lot of other spools need some tube as center. This spool does not need other parts, only 2x m4 screws to mount both parts of the spool together. I tried to remove as much material as possible to speed up printing, but still retain enough strength.
    It has a large 100mm center, so 3 mm filament will not bent too much during winding. There are holes to hold filament when starting to wind. Also there are holes to hold the end of the filament after winding. The spool is designed for a Lyman type of winder (see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:380987 ), where the winder motor rests on the edge of the spool.
    This spool belongs to my filament maker, that also contains a filament puller (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:677144)

Print it with your favourite material of choice. I used ABS, 0.3mm layer and 25% fill.
No support is needed. The holes have a thin piece of plastic for support during printing. Just put a small screw driver through them to remove it. For a spool you need to print this design twice. The parts are keyed, so will only fit one way together.
It has space for 4 screws, but only will need two for mounting. Use two opposite holes for the screws. You will need to mount a m4 nut in the nut traps. Only one nut per side needed. Again watch that you only use 2 opposite holes. The best way to mount the nut is to heat the nut with a lighter or soldering iron, and press it gently in place. Success!

author: hradec

description.text:
Modelo topográfico de Yosemite Valley en la zona Oeste de Sierra Nevada en el estado de California, EE.UU. Creado a partir de datos ASTER GLOBAL DEM descargados desde:
http://earthexplorer.usgs.gov/
Los datos están disponibles en malla de 1 segundo de arco (aproximadamente 30m en el ecuador).
Para la obtención del modelo STL, se ha usado DEMto3d, una herramienta útil y fácil de usar para covertir MDE (modelos digitales de elevaciones) en modelos STL, listos para imprimir en 3D. DEMto3D está disponible en la siguiente dirección: http://www.demto3d.com/
DEMto3D funciona como una extensión disponibles para los softwares SIG gratuitos Kosmo (http://www.opengis.es/) y QGIS (http://www.qgis.org/en/site/)

Topography model of Yosemite Valley in the western Sierra Nevada mountains of California, USA. Created from ASTER GLOBAL DEM data downloaded from http://earthexplorer.usgs.gov/
The data are posted on a 1 arc-second (approximately 30–m at the equator) grid.
To obtain the STL model, I used DEMto3d, an easy and useful tool to convert DEM data to STL models ready to print. This tool is available in the next link http://www.demto3d.com/
DEMto3D is a plugin available for free GIS software Kosmo (http://www.opengis.es/) and QGIS (http://www.qgis.org/en/site/)

comments.text: Hola que tal que tanto de altura se pueden obtener?..... tengo pensado imprimir varias montañas pero de 200mm de altura
comments.author: EduardoMakerSpace

comments.text: Hola, la altura final del modelo depende de la escala que definas. Una vez definida, como máximo se le puede aplicar una exageración de x3. Por ejemplo, si tuvieras un MDE con alturas máximas de 3000 metros y quisieras imprimirlo a escala 1:50000, la altura del modelo final sería 60 mm. Si se aplicase una exageración con factor x3 la altura del modelo final quedaría en 180 mm. (A esta altura final del modelo DEMto3D le suma 2 mm que hacen de base, para poder imprimir cotas a 0 metros)

title: Ariel Atom Go-Pro mount (behind front suspension)

description.text: The best location (IMO) for the GoPro on an Ariel Atom is just behind the front suspension. You get a great view of the road and you get to see the spring in action. However.... There is no good point to attach a Go-Pro and the bar behind the suspension is on an 11 degree angle so using the standard attachments either puts your video on an angle or requires several links to level the video, which raises the height of the camera and makes it more susceptible to vibrations. This mount snugly attaches to the bar behind the suspension and compensates for the 11 degree slope. The camera is rock solid and below the eye line. You can see a video of me sinking the threads into the lower half, which lets me use screws to really tighten it down here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Dhf08s35SGY And the shot you can get here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sDaoSM_lJWg

title: Dihedral tilt top for RCExplorer Tricopter V3 (5 degrees)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Dihedral tilt top for the RCExplorer tricopter V3. Experimental! For use when cutting the arms in half and building a mini tricopter. Derivative of David Windeståls excellent work. Get the frame and necessary servo at http://www.rcexplorer.se/shop. Use M3x35 hex and a washer for the tilt mechanism (original was M3x40)
(For the servo horn version, use M3 locknut and M3x30 hex screw)
Use M3x20 hex screws for the front legs.
Use two M3x6 hex screws for the tilt.
Use two M3x20 for the rear leg
Use two M3 locknuts for the tilt bottom Two kinds: NTM style hole pattern and Elite style hole pattern (rotated 90 degrees) Hole spacing 19mm. I did a small test of the functionality of the dihedral tilt mechanism here: http://youtu.be/oGvY1ehM_Vs Buy the original tilt mechanism from RCExplorer.se (http://rcexplorer.se/product/tricopter-tilt-mechanism-3d-printed/) or download the STLs: http://rcexplorer.se/downloads/

Print the tilt top, tilt bottom, servo holder and mount tops solid, preferably 0.1 layer height.  
Print the legs to suit your needs, lightest build would be 15% infill, 0.2 layer height.

Inspired by this http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3981 and this http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5584 One of the first things I would like to print when I finish my Mendel is a roller bearing. I am also playing around with OpenSCAD so I have started writing a script to generated either complete printable bearings or just the races with an optional ball cage. The end result I would like is a lookup table of common bearing sizes, or size to suit.

The script is parametric, but has no error catching so don't try and generate a file with an ID larger than the OD for instance. OD - Outside diameter
ID - Inside diameter
B - Thickness
cage - Draw a cage to hold the balls (yes/no)
balls -Draw the balls (yes/no)
calc_no_balls - Calculate the number of balls (yes/no)
ball_num_overide - Manual number of balls if above = NO

author: Wiltonpdj

description.text: This is an adjustable camera mount for an ordinary paint pole. The pole is used to get your camera up high above the ground without kites, balloons, or expensive toy helicopters. All for the cost of less then five dollars!   This will allow you to take photos easily at a height you cannot reach.  The photo of the Mini Cooper shows the difference between a eye level shot on the street and the second shot using the paint pole camera mount.  The camera is a small hand held digital with a ten second timer so it gives you more than enough time to take a photo.  But any camera with a timer should work fine. The pole used for the second car shot was only four feet in length imagine what a 12 or 15 foot pole would be like.

The paint pole camera mount was made at the QC Co-lab hackerspace in Davenport Iowa using a MakerBot 3D printer.  Along with the files that I here to print out the 3D parts, you will also need the following hardware parts. One 1/4 x 3/4" bolt, one 1/4 X 2 1/2" bolt, one 1/4 x 3" bolt, four 1/4 inch washers, one 1/4 inch wing nut, one 1/4" nut and two self tapping screws. Assembly the "U" shaped part (Tilt mount 2) to the cup and stud using the three inch bolt with washers on both ends and a nut to hold it together.  (See exploded view image) Insert the "L" shaped part (Tilt mount 1) between the upper arms of the "U" shaped part making sure to have the square end horizontal with the entire assembly. Run a 1/4 x 3" bolt through the aligned holes and secure with a washer and wing nut on the opposite end.   The squared end is where the camera is mounted using a 1/4 X 3/4" bolt that is inserted through the bottom of the square end of the "L" part and into the camera mount.  The 1/4" bolt worked fine on my camera as this seems to be a standard size for a camera mount. Insert the assembly stud inside your paint pole and the cup on the outside of your paint pole. These may have to be test fitted and sanded before assembly. You should remove the normal roller mount found on a paint pole and attach this assembly on to the pole. Use two self tapping screws to hold the camera mount to your paint pole.   The wing nut bolt assembly going through the "U" and "L" parts can be loosened so that the camera mount can be adjusted to tilt the camera up or down as desired when shooting photos.  Be careful to make sure the wing nut is secure before moving the pole around to take a photo.  Also when bringing your camera down from any height take great care as it could easily be damaged if you drop it on the ground.

comments.text: I was going to post a picture of my print but the license you've chosed won't let me do that.. =-O
comments.author: Gael_Langevin

comments.text: You can list the required metal as "parts".
comments.author: MarcusWolschon

comments.text: 1 KG or 2.2 pounds? Wow that is a lot of weight to be moving around on a pole that could be 12 or 15 feet above the ground.  Not sure I would want to be handling a camera that weighed that much on the ground much less up in the air.  I think the mount is plenty strong to handle the weight of say a digital 35mm camera or a small video camera.  Anything larger than that would be difficult to control if there were a good breeze blowing on the day you are shooting. A safety line would be an idea along with a platform below the mount so that you could rest the camera and pole assembly on the ground and not have the camera touch the ground.  All good ideas for the next version.

description.text: A simple typewriter style keycap inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:417509 (which was too big to fit on my keyboard). The big issue I've had with all the other cherry keycaps is that the stem won't fit on the switches without a ton of cutting and filing. In this design, the walls of the stem are so thin that the printer ignored them and just printed 4 posts which fit perfectly. Win. The key in the picture is printed with ABS. I have printed it with PLA as well with good results. The ABS fits a little more snug on the switch, which may be due to shrinkage.

100% fill
0.15mm layer thickness (adjust to your liking)
0.8mm shell thickness I reduced the print speed to 40mm/s (down from 50) to help with the accuracy of the stem. I also set the first layer thickness to 0.06 larger (down from 0.3) and the layer line width to 50% larger (down from 100%) than the rest of the layers. This helped with the detail in the letters, but wasn't really necessary for printing the blank keycap. It might be worth noting that those default sizes are for my Ultimaker 2 as I don't know much about other kinds of printers.

title: Cutting board with drain groves and handle

description.text: Cutting board with drain grove and handle

This is a box for your RAMPS 1.4 electronics that requires absolutely no hardware.  Print one out to protect your electronics from accidental shorts and damage.  It has plenty of vent holes, along with a version of the lid for mounting a centrifugal fan for extra cooling.  The lid securely snaps onto the top of the box, leaving holes for all of your cables.

Print the box and lid with your preferred settings.  There is some bridging, but it wasn't much of an issue for me.  The first couple of layers above the bridges didn't laminate together, so I just tore them off and the box still works the same!  There are pillars a few pillars that are meant to make the bridge spans shorter.  You will probably have to remove these to make space for your cables.  I was able to break mine free by hand.   
After everything is printed, drop your RAMPS board inside, snap the lid in place and snap the fan into the lid.  
The easiest way to wire the fan is to simply screw the positive and negative leads into the main power terminals of your RAMPS board.  This way the fan will be on whenever you have power to your board.

This is a project to make an opensource robot that moves like a dog. Right now this project is more of an OpenSCad tutorial than anything else. However, I will be covering more aspects of the design when I have time. The tutorial is in the form of a 10 minute youtube video.
Episode 1 http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LmKnvEcPTk8 The OpenSCad source code in this video is included at the bottom. I am intentionally not including STL files for now as I know the design will change. Episode 2 "DogBot Math":
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qaqrHuw4qY8
The Source files for this episode are included at the bottom in a zip file. Thanks goes to tbuser and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2054 for supplying the openscad fonts. Episode 3 "DogBot Electronics": http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8-Y19SUuzC8 Epsiode 4 "Dogbot Learns to Feel, Part 2":
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XgJe5fNaTj0 UPDATE:(7/11/2011) Episode 5 is now available:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sfWb2gXHOMg

comments.text: Nice job on the video.  I actually had no idea that OpenSCAD could do animations!
comments.author: dmatsumoto

comments.text: I like your video about openscad pretty helpful into into designing with it. Awesome project can't wait to see more. Will this be printable on a makerbot?
comments.author: themitch22

comments.text: At DogBot's current state the print area of the makerbot would not be able to print all the parts, but the scad files are configurable. If you choose a smaller servo than I am using and pull back leg_upper_length from 65mm to 30mm, you'll have a smaller robot, but one printable on a makerbot! Or, someone in the community (possibly me if there is demand) can redesign the largest parts into multiple parts. So a makerbot print area should be big enough to build a skeleton, just not at current state.

description.text:
An egg shaped box.  
UPDATE: Someone requested the source files so I uploaded them. They are ipt files made using Inventor 2013 Pro. You can get a trial version from the Autodesk University website.  
Enjoy!

A little last minute for easter but you should still have time to print one for your loved one. One of the body has the text: Happy easter!
The other one is blank. Print 1 cover and 1 body. For me, the cover didn't always fit on the first try depending on which plastic I used. If it does that just sand the inside of the body opening a little bit (doesn't take much).

a friend broke fixing to close the port veranda is modeled and then I printed it
i use google sketchup

If you like my work I hope you'll consider supporting me on Pateron: https://www.patreon.com/3DPrintingProfessor Subscribe to me on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/user/mrjoesays DutchMogul's original set had some problems that made it fail when I printed it. I tried to preserve the feel of the original in my edits which were:
  • Lowered the platforms to remove overhang
  • Raised the Rooks helmet to make it taller than the pawn w/o the platform
  • Thickened the neck of the bishop.
  • Thickened the chimney on the king's hat
  • Put the pieces on a plate ready to print
    • Version 2 also scaldes up all the pieces, the pawn by a little bit less to make them closer to normal chess pieces sizes.

description.text:
A fan duct to guide the air from the bottom fan, over the motherboard.  
Tap the holes, remove the nuts from the fan and use the screws directly in the fan duct.  
Edit 1: Added the Sketchup file, so you can edit it as you like.

• Tap the holes in the fan duct
  • Remove the nuts from the fan
  • Use the same screws directly in the fan duct.
    • Optional: There is an extra hole you can use if you want things to sit even tighter, but you will have to drill a hole in the machine.

description.text: This is an outdated (but still playable using Third Edition rules) version of Pocket-Tactics. For the new (and much improved) Fourth Edition sets and pieces, check out this collection. We'll be updating the new edition to include rules for all of the Third Edition units, so if you have printed them (or want to), check in for updates and eventually all of those pieces' rules will be available. We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...) Enjoy!

comments.text: Hello, do itch guild have it's own tiles ? Or can we mix all the tiles of the game whatever the guild played ?
comments.author: Wapata

comments.text: Oh, each faction has its own 10 tiles, so if two factions are playing against one another, mix all twenty and draw from those. However, you totally can just play with a big batch of random tiles if you like. That makes for a more challenging game, especially for factions that are really tied to their tile types (such as Elves are with forests).
comments.author: Wapata

This is not written in the rules I think. We better have one container for each faction then.

title: E3D_V5_MT Modular hotend mount for the Ultimaker Original
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: A split mount for the popular E3D V5 hotend that can be replaced without removing the gantry rods (after first removing the original mount). Drop in compatible accessory mounting holes for the Annular Cooling V2 (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:124237) Has a dove tail accessory rail where a depth gauge attachement can be slotted in. See attachment photo. A finned bracket is also provided if you want to better confine the airflow over the radiator fins and drop their temperature a few more degrees.

• 2x LM8LUU linear bearings (or the ones comming out of the old mount)
  • 4x M3x45mm bolts
  • 2x M3x10mm bolts
  • 4x M3x20mm bolts
  • 2x M3x30mm bolts
  • 12x M3 nuts
  • 2x 2.5x1mm cable ties
  • 1x Annular Cooling V2 (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:124237)
    • For the dial gauge rail:
  • 1x M4x20mm bolt
  • 1x M4 nut
  • 1x M3x20mm bolt
  • 1x M3 nut
  • 1x Dial gauge
    • Print all parts on their larger flats although some can print on their sides. Keeping the same print orientation makes a better stack.
    You can print all parts at 50% infill and 0.2mm layer thickness, but I prefer printing the bracket at 100% infill, especially the thin square one. Enjoy!

Decorative two piece Asian inspired lantern with geometric design. Different variant of my other lantern. Designed to print without support.

Print out both pieces. Designed to work without support. Hints:
-The bottom would look great with .25mm layers, 2 perimeters and low infill. Because of its shallow slope, the top would work better with under .25mm layers, 3 perimeters and low infill.
-The columns of the geometric design can get sheared off by the nozzle, especially at smaller scales, and especially if your slicer does the perimeters first and then comes back to infill them solid. I had to revise the design several times to make them stronger.
-The top is supposed to snap onto the base, but you may have to scrape some plastic away once printed to get the proper clearances.
-Check out the attached sketchup file. The geometric design is its own component and can be edited independently. Changing just one panel will update all 6 automatically.
-The STLs were processed through netfabb so should be error free. Check out http://cloud.netfabb.com/
